channel.title: Close
channel.description: Thank you to the people that attempted to help, I always appreciate advice that is provided regardless if it was useful or not.

item.title: Close
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Well I don’t see why you couldn’t have told us that in the first place, would’ve understood perfectly and recommended appropriate parts, but whatever, case closed.

item.title: Close
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Spades, post:17, topic:527778”]For a server, if you plan on doing a “proper” server, I would recommend an Antec Rackmount. You can snatch one on ebay for like 50 bucks if you’re lucky. Then you can get a UPS and rack that, along with sticking it in an actual server rack.

Question: If you don’t have a lot of knowledge about computers, how are you going to set up and manage an actual server?[/quote]
It wouldn’t have been a Server so a rack-mount wouldn’t of helped.

Answer to your question: It wasn’t a Server hence why I don’t need any knowledge to that in any respects & this thread was made because some parts aren’t consumer grade parts so I figured I might need a bit of help figuring out what I need before I buy the parts and realize I’m missing something. Just because you have some workstation graded parts doesn’t mean you can’t use them in your build (that isn’t a Server). What led you to the conclusion I don’t know much about ‘Computers’?

For anyone curious I can now tell you one of the reasons why I was going to make the build (supplier had some issues so I’m just going to go with a normal high end build) the CPU’s wouldn’t of been the retail versions of the CPU’s, they would have been Engineering Samples. They would perform just like the final versions of the hardware but they would have some compatibility issues etc.

If you look up the motherboard you will be able to tell it would fit in a normal well spaced case like the ones I originally planned on getting so you jackasses should have stopped talking out of your ass when you saw their was Xeons involved in this build (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workstation , I would have been using the computer as a workstation to make me money on but now I’m going to have to do that on a different build).

Now I no longer require help since I’m not using those CPU’s anymore. So, thanks to the people that attempted to answer my questions (special thanks to RSCShadow since I’m going to use the windowed R4 variant of that case).

Can somebody please close this thread.

Read full topic

item.title: Close
item.dc:creator: @Spades Spades
item.description:
@Spades wrote:

For a server, if you plan on doing a “proper” server, I would recommend an Antec Rackmount. You can snatch one on ebay for like 50 bucks if you’re lucky. Then you can get a UPS and rack that, along with sticking it in an actual server rack.

Question: If you don’t have a lot of knowledge about computers, how are you going to set up and manage an actual server?

Read full topic

item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

Spades:

I mean, you are wanting to build a high powered server, you are going to be spending thousands of dollars. The only thing I can imagine is if you are trying to start some sort of Hosting company or something.

Re-read my previous post. I have no intention of explaining what I’m doing and why. As I said it’s too much effort unless I tell you what I’m doing which I’m not going to.
If you think I’m dumb enough to blow money on something I don’t need then fair enough but please don’t try to convince me.

[quote=“chillwitm888, post:4, topic:527778”]Just apply arctic paste on the CPU. Are you an audofile? If you are then get any creative brand sound card within your price range. They all seem good, my friend has a 45$ one and it sounds great. However, I can’t tell too much of a diff since idc
Integrated ones do fine.
Liquid builds aren’t bad but they are abit more costly
Yeah so if you want me to provide you with a build
I’ll do it
Just list what you want(features… Don’t say just surfing the Internet or playing bf3 on low) and I’ll make a build one also list your price range (if you do want me to send me to send you a build[/quote]
I see. I am not but I don’t want to skimp out on quality (when it comes to this part since this part is pretty cheap in comparison to others); I’ll probably go with Xonar. I already know almost every part I’m going to use, just the little things I’m still deciding on. Of course as pricing changes I’ll modify the build but right now I’m happy with my choices. Thanks for the offer though :D.

item.title: Close
item.dc:creator: @Spades Spades
item.description:
@Spades wrote:

You don’t need a dual CPU motherboard, those are for commercial servers. Hell, if you want to spend a lot of money, get a high end CPU, high end Motherboard, with 8GB+ of RAM, with a SSD, as your primary then get a 7200RPM+ SATA III HDD and call it a day. That thing alone will blow the doors off anything you can throw at it. We use them at my work for camera servers, they are at max rating with Windows ratings. Dual slot CPU Mobo is not necessary by any means. Even if you are trying to run multiple things from 1 server. High end i7 overclocked.

Read full topic

item.title: Close
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

Because I need a lot of power and it’s a little side project to make me a profit if I decide not to keep the build for some reason.

Audio quality matters.

I’m not looking for liquid cooling, that’s more for OC’ed processors… The CPU’s won’t be hot. Liquid cooling for workstation type builds aren’t a very good choice. Also, on another note that liquid cooling doesn’t support lga 1356. You can get some pretty quiet fans that are powerful which will work a treat for a Xeon build I’m sure.

I know that, I’m asking if you plug those wires into the ‘pin headers’.

Read full topic

item.title: Close
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

A little side question, what the hell are you building this for?

Kidpaparoach:

Firstly, sound; what would I need within the desktop? I believe some motherboards have this inbuilt but the one I’ll be getting doesn’t have it (that I can see) since it’s a compact workstation motherboard.

If audio quality doesn’t matter, pretty much any sound card will do.

Kidpaparoach:

Secondly, CPU cooling; what cooling would you recommend? What would I need (i.e. thermal paste), the CPU’s won’t be OC’ed but I’d have two of them so what does that mean in relation to non stock fans since they tend to be big etc? The CPU’s won’t be OC’ed since their Xeons… but I’d like them to be cool temperature wise and I’d like the system as a whole to be as silent as possible.

What you’re looking for is liquid cooling system.

Kidpaparoach:

Thirdly, front case USBs. The onboard i/o has 2x usb pin headers; is their a way to hook them up to the front case USBs? (I’m not entirely sure what a usb pin header is)

Case has wires for the front USB ports, you just plug them into the motherboard.

Read full topic
